material.mattext: The blue balls are binding to the enzymes using the same binding site that would be used by the substrate. The blue balls are competing for the substrate binding site, and are therefore will be competitive inhibitors. The black curve represents the velocity versus substrate obtained in the absence of any inhibitor. Using the radio dials at the right, select substrate concentrations of [S]=2 or [S]=4. The observed decrease in the velocity for the reaction in the presence of the inhibitor is lowered because:
The amount of free enzyme is decreased, therefore the substrate has fewer places to bind, reducing [ES].
The substate binds to the inhibitor in solution, reducing the concentration of substrate, therefore reducing the velocity.
If an enzyme has an inhibitor bound to it, can it bind substrate?
The amount of ES complex that is formed is proportional to the amount of free enzyme (and substrate).
Correct. At these substrate levels, a fraction of the enzyme molecules are "benched" because they have an inhibitor in the active site and can't bind substrate.

Incorrect. The inhibitor does not bind to the substrate. Rather, at these substrate levels, a fraction of the enzyme molecules are "benched" because they have an inhibitor in the active site and can't bind substrate.
